body: Junior doctors’ leaders are set to enter fresh talks with the government on Monday, signalling a small breakthrough in the bitter contractual dispute. The British Medical Association (BMA) has agreed to restart talks with Jeremy Hunt’s department over contentious issues including Saturday pay. The talks are seen as the best chance of a peace deal to end the eight month-long protest over the new contract, following the first all-out strike in NHS history last month. However, there was fresh opposition to Hunt on Sunday as junior doctors in Manchester urged Mike Deegan, the chief executive of Manchester Royal Infirmary, not to impose the contract even if he is ordered to by the health secretary. The petition, which organisers say has been signed by about 2,500 doctors, patients and other members of the public, was backed by Labour MP Jeff Smith on Sunday. Speaking outside his constituency office in Withington, south Manchester, Smith said: “Labour has supported the junior doctors throughout the dispute because we think they have a strong case that the government haven’t been prepared to listen to. This is a demonstration of our support and why I’ve been happy to sign the petition. “Now that we’ve got this agreement that there’s going to be a new set of negotiations let’s hope that something positive will come out of it and that both sides can agree and move forward. “The petition has been set up over the last few weeks saying that it’s the wrong time to impose it [the contract] – let’s hope that the contract negotiations get to a position where there’s no need for the petition and can get to an agreement.” Dr Johann Malawana, the chairman of the BMA’s junior doctors committee, said he hoped “real progress can now be made to ending this dispute”. The BMA will call for any contract offer, whether it is agreed or not, to be voted on by junior doctors. Malawana said: “The BMA has agreed to re-enter talks with the government on outstanding issues in this dispute, which include, but are not limited to, unsocial hours. “Junior doctors’ concerns extend far beyond pay and our principle in talks will be to deliver a fair contract that does not discriminate against women or any other group, one which addresses the recruitment and retention crisis in the NHS and which provides the basis for delivering a world-class health service. “The BMA will also call for any contract offer – agreed or not – to be put to a referendum of junior doctors, as is usual following a contract negotiation. We hope that with both parties back around the negotiating table, real progress can now be made to ending this dispute through talks.” The new talks were met with cautious optimism from some of the junior doctors who signed the Manchester petition. Ruth Wiggans, 32, a respiratory registrar and clinical research fellow, said she was “cautiously hopeful” that the new talks would lead to a breakthrough. “Nobody wants to be on strike. I’m glad the government have agreed to enter negotiations, I just hope they’re willing to do it on equal terms,” she said. “So far they haven’t been negotiations, they’ve been a series of clauses. If the negotiations lead to something positive that can only be a good thing for everyone involved. But I’m very cautious about what’s going to happen now.” Dr Piyush Pushkar, 32, a psychiatry trainee at Manchester Royal Infirmary, said: “We were heartbroken at having to strike and are desperate not to have to do so again. So I am delighted that Jeremy Hunt has finally deigned to return to talks with the BMA, even if it took an all-out strike to bring him to that position. “All we want is to be able to work in a sustainable and fair NHS, with a contract that is safe. Hopefully, this time he will listen to all of our concerns, rather than just wittering on about Saturday pay as if this could be isolated as a simple pay dispute.” A Department of Health spokesman said it “welcomed the BMA’s decision to return to talks” and that it had always wanted to see a “negotiated solution”. “From Monday, we will be looking for resolution on the small number of outstanding issues that separated both parties in February, principally Saturday pay, but also other issues that affect the motivation, recruitment and retention of junior doctors,” he said.
webTitle: Junior doctors prepare for fresh talks over contracts
